headline: Inside Politics
subHeadline: Clyburn: Concerned About Biden Outreach To Voters; Charlamagne Tha God No Longer Backing Biden Warns Black Voters Could Sit This Election Out; Biden Speaks At Mother Emanuel AME Church In SC. Aired 12:30-1p ET

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: President Biden is set to speak soon from the historic Mother Emanuel AME Church in Charleston, South Carolina. You're looking at James Clyburn, the leader -- former leader in the United States House of Representatives. He is introducing the president, so we're going to watch and listen for that, which should happen momentarily.Of course, we should remind our viewers that this is where nine congregants were killed in 2015 in a massacre by a white supremacist. And let's talk as we wait for President Biden to start speaking and discuss the fact that he, the president, last week, gave a big speech on democracy. Today, he is going down to commemorate what happened again almost a decade ago and to talk about extremism, to talk about hate and to obviously court black voters. LEIGH ANN CALDWELL, EARLY 202 CO-AUTHOR, THE WASHINGTON POST: Yes. First of all, I can't believe that was a decade ago.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I know. Nine years.

utterances.speaker: CALDWELL
utterances.sentences: Really incredible. But, absolutely, South Carolina is the first voting state for Democrats. Well, New Hampshire defied. Democrats rules in this going first, but President Biden knows that -- well, first of all, I'd say this is very important to him personally, of course, but also President Biden knows that black voters are also critical to his reelection.There has been polling that has showed that black voters are not as engaged or excited about President Biden, and it also plays into an issue that President Biden has focused on as well with little results. It's also gun violence. Something that Congress has been unable to solve. So this is an issue, of course, that is important to President Biden, but it's also important politically, too.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. And James Clyburn, who again is speaking now, he was on with Jake Tapper yesterday on State of the Union. Clyburn, for those who don't remember, kind of single handedly resurrected Joe Biden's political career before the South Carolina primary four years ago, endorsed him and helped get him elected and then Biden never looked back.Clyburn talked to Jake about his concerns with the Biden reelection campaign. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. JAMES CLYBURN (D), SOUTH CAROLINA: I have no problem with the Biden administration and what it has done. My problem is that we have not been able to break through that MAGA wall in order to get to people exactly what this president has done. So this president is keeping his promises, but keep -- people keep focusing on the one or two things he did not get accomplished.

utterances.speaker: DANIEL STRAUSS, CNN NATIONAL POLITICAL REPORTER
utterances.sentences: You always got to give it to Congressman Clyburn. You always know where he stands.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HEIDI PRZYBYLA, NATIONAL INVESTIGATIVE CORRESPONDENT, POLITICO
utterances.sentences: It's a test case. He doesn't need South Carolina. He's the nominee, but it's a test case for whether he can get some of those black voters back. And I do say back with numbers because the percentages show that he slid with black voters since the last election.And on the point, though, about course correction, I talked to some Biden folks earlier this morning, and they are over the moon that after that first democracy speech, they raised $1 million. I said, that is a very good sign that this new framework that the Biden campaign is going to be using is going to be very effective, especially when look at what happened today. We're cutting between Donald Trump talking about civil war, using the words hostages to describe the January 6th rioters and that is going to be the juxtaposition now that's just naturally going to unfold during the campaign is that it really is about a choice between democracy and potentially autocracy and a more authoritarian type tilt in this country.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Let's look at what Quentin Fulks, who is the number two at the Biden campaign said to CNN and a piece for CNN.com. "We're not going to wait and parachute into these communities the last minute and ask them for their vote. We're going to earn their vote. Voters of color are the ones who have the most at stake in this election, and we need to make sure that every single one of them understands the choice in front of them."

utterances.speaker: CALDWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, so one thing, one important element to this plan is also Vice President Kamala Harris. The Biden campaign has been intentional and think that Harris going, especially into black communities, is going to be really critical for the campaign leading in to the reelection.But President Biden has a lot of work to do on a lot of demographics. And that goes to what your point was, is that people are worried that maybe that a course correction in your words might be necessary.

utterances.speaker: PRZYBYLA
utterances.sentences: It might need another influence or two other than Clyburn to speak to the younger black generation. Well, it was very effective last time when you talked about demographics, there's a lot of overlap there between younger voters and black voters. You put them together. That's like exactly where his problem spot is.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. And-- go Daniel.

utterances.speaker: STRAUSS
utterances.sentences: If you ask most Democrats, you'll hear them say that the concern is not a big migration to Trump. It is complacency. It is that these key interest groups are going to stay at home. And that is the real worry among the Biden campaign right now. That if they do not remind these voters that propelled Biden in 2020 to come out and vote, that this is not a sure thing, they will stay home and the outcome --

utterances.speaker: PRZYBYLA
utterances.sentences: Like Hillary in 2016.

utterances.speaker: STRAUSS
utterances.sentences: Yes. The outcome will be very different.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Well, Charlamagne tha God, who we all know was a big supporter of Joe Biden four years ago, is now saying that he's concerned that if there's choices between Biden and Trump, that the option is to stay home and that he suspects the couch could win. And that's exactly what they're trying to try to avoid with this speech aside from the obvious which is this is a very important topic that he -- it is very personal to him and we are waiting for the president to speak there in Charleston, South Carolina.We're going to take a quick break and hear from him probably on the other side. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: We want to get straight to President Biden speaking at the Mother Emanuel AME Church in South Carolina. Let's listen.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I rest my case.(LAUGHTER AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: ALL
utterances.sentences: Four more years!

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you, please. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ALL
utterances.sentences: Four more years! Four more years! Four more years!

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ALL
utterances.sentences: Four more years! Four more years! Four more years!

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you, thank you, thank you. Thank you. Thank you. It's going to go to my head.(LAUGHTER) Please. Thank you. Jim --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We love you!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If you really care about the lives lost here, then you should honor the lives lost and call for a ceasefire in Palestine.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ceasefire now!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Ceasefire now!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ceasefire now! Ceasefire now!

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: That's all right. That's all right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ceasefire now! Ceasefire now! Ceasefire now! Ceasefire now! Ceasefire now! Ceasefire now! Ceasefire now! Ceasefire now!(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ceasefire now! (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: ALL
utterances.sentences: Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years! Four more years!

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Look, folks --

utterances.speaker: ALL
utterances.sentences: Four more years! Four more years!

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I understand their -- I understand their passion. And I've been quietly working -- I've been quietly working with the Israeli government to get them to reduce and significantly get out of Gaza. I've been using all that I can to do that.(APPLAUSE) But I understand the passion. Look, folks, after the Civil --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You're an understanding person. You're an understanding person.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: They don't realize that. You're a good man.
